answer_llm: The course will cover the bare minimum of theory, focusing more on practical applications. The theory will be addressed only at an intuitive level, meaning that in-depth derivations, such as the gradient update rule for logistic regression, will not be included. Instead, the emphasis will be on how to use logistic regression and interpret the results.
answer_orig:
The bare minimum. The focus is more on practice, and we'll cover the theory only on the intuitive level.: https://mlbookcamp.com/article/python
For example, we won't derive the gradient update rule for logistic regression (there are other great courses for that), but we'll cover how to use logistic regression and make sense of the results.

answer_llm: To be prepared for this course, you should know the basics of Python, which include how to run a Jupyter notebook, how to import libraries, how to declare a variable, and some important operations regarding data analysis. answer_orig:
Check this article. If you know everything in this article, you know enough. If you don’t, read the article and join the coursIntroduction to Pythone too :)
Introduction to Python – Machine Learning Bookcamp
You can follow this English course from the OpenClassrooms e-learning platform, which is free and covers the python basics for data analysis: Learn Python Basics for Data Analysis - OpenClassrooms . It is important to know some basics such as: how to run a Jupyter notebook, how to import libraries (and what libraries are), how to declare a variable (and what variables are) and some important operations regarding data analysis.
(Mélanie Fouesnard)

question: Is there a guide to set up TensorFlow with GPU on Ubuntu?

answer_llm:
To configure GPU support for TensorFlow on your Ubuntu machine, follow these steps:

1. Install Nvidia drivers from [Nvidia's website](https://www.nvidia.com/download/index.aspx).
2. Install the CUDA toolkit (version 11.x.x) from the [CUDA Toolkit Archive](https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-toolkit-archive).
3. Install cuDNN by following the instructions on the [cuDNN download page](https://developer.nvidia.com/rdp/cudnn-download).
4. Finally, install TensorFlow with GPU support using pip.

For a detailed guide, you can refer to this article: [Setup TensorFlow with GPU support on Ubuntu](https://knowmledge.com/2023/12/07/ml-zoomcamp-2023-project/).

It should help you with the installation process. Additionally, you may need to install CUDA and cuDNN, which are essential for running TensorFlow with GPU support.

question: Can you direct me to a resource for installing TensorFlow with GPU on Ubuntu?

answer_llm:
To set up TensorFlow with GPU support on Ubuntu, you can follow these guidelines:

1. **Install Nvidia drivers**: Visit [Nvidia's official website](https://www.nvidia.com/download/index.aspx) to download and install the appropriate drivers for your GPU.

2. **Install CUDA & cuDNN**: You need to set up CUDA and cuDNN to allow TensorFlow to utilize the GPU. You can find the installation instructions for CUDA [here](https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-toolkit-archive) and for cuDNN [here](https://developer.nvidia.com/rdp/cudnn-download).

3. **Install TensorFlow**: After ensuring CUDA and cuDNN are installed properly, you can install TensorFlow with GPU support. Use the TensorFlow installation guide for Linux, which you can find [here](https://www.tensorflow.org/install/pip#linux_1).

4. **Export Environment Variables**: Run the following command in your terminal to set the necessary environment variable (make sure to replace `$CONDA_PREFIX` with your actual conda environment path):
   ```bash
   echo 'export XLA_FLAGS=--xla_gpu_cuda_data_dir=$CONDA_PREFIX/lib/> $CONDA_PREFIX/etc/conda/activate.d/env_vars.sh'
   ```

For a more detailed guide, you can refer to this resource: [ML Zoomcamp 2023 Project Article](https://knowmledge.com/2023/12/07/ml-zoomcamp-2023-project/). 

Make sure you have the correct hardware to support these installations and configurations.
answer_orig: Here is an article that worked for me: https://knowmledge.com/2023/12/07/ml-zoomcamp-2023-project/
question: What is the procedure to set up TensorFlow GPU on Ubuntu?

answer_llm:
To join a channel in Slack, follow these steps:

1. Click “All channels” at the top of your left sidebar. If you don't see this option, click “More” to find it.
2. Browse the list of public channels in your workspace, or use the search bar to search by channel name or description.
3. Select a channel from the list to view it.
4. Click Join Channel.

For more detailed instructions, you can visit this link: https://slack.com/help/articles/205239967-Join-a-channel.
